text:
One of the biggest misconceptions I see always, is bootstrapped can’t afford.  This is totally a wrong and baseless assumption.

Being bootstrapped ==! Affordability!  MailChimp (now acquired by Intuit) is bootstrapped.  Zoho Corp is still a bootstrapped.

Bootstrapped only means no external funding.  The funding for payroll etc can still come for founders and or even revenue.  So, can’t assume on the affordability purely based on whether or no funded.

elements.text:

text: Well i thought it was understood that bootstrapped and very early stage is what people meant here when they said they can't afford. The examples quoted above for high hikes are bootstrapped companies in either later stages or post pm fit stages. But happy to learn if my assumption is wrong

text:
Percentage is (of appraisal) should be the same as the any industry standard.  (usually 15 - 50% for a base of 20LPA).

Now, a bootstrapped startup may choose to give some of it usually in terms of further ESOPs and or a combination of revenue based bonus (or trigger based even future funding rounds) to fill the deficit.

The point it, whether or not bootstrapped — talent market is open in nature.  A bootstrapped founders usually always work a combination of things under their control to propose an offer to retain a talent.

The finer detail for the OP is to see how well he believes in the idea and what the future looks like for the company’s success.  So, the decision is less about the percentage and more about future bets (which I personally believe that in early stage, pre-revenue, employees should be considered as founding teams and should have an equity no less than 3%).

text:
What's a good %age of Esops wrt overall CTC? 

I have seen start-ups offer 10-50% of total salary as a ESOP component. Especially in early and series A-B funded startups. Eg. a 60 lac package with 30 as base + variable and 30 lac wort ESOPs. 
As a candidate how do you decide whether it's a good offer considering min 4 year vesting period and you usually don't know the financials of a private company?
